trial_identification.studytitle: Prevention of hypothermia in the delivery room for preterm infants <30 weeks gestation
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A comparison of plactic wrap and conventional method at birth in infants <30 weeks gestation in the prevention of hypothermia in the delivery room.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Conditions of unknown or disputed aetiology (such as chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgic encephalomyelitis)

interventions.interventions: The trial will have two groups: control and experimental. In the experimental group a plastic wrap will be used after birth, in the control group will remain standard procedure. The duration of the intervention will be 120 minutes from birth.
interventions.comparator: Standard care after birth, as recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP). The control treatment will be until 120 minutes from birth.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Temperatures will be taken at birth and then every 30 minutes until the neonate is 120 minutes old. A thermometer will be used to measure the axilla temperature of each neonate.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hypoglycaemia, this will be measured by the blood gas machine.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Within the first 120 minutes of birth

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Angus Smith Drive Douglas TSV QLD 4814

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Angus Smith Drive Douglas TSV QLD 4814

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To investigate whether the short term use of plasctic occlusive wrapping on premature neonates, immediately after delivery, is an effective method in preventing hypothermia during resuscitation in the delivery room and operating theatre. These babies are at higher risk of hypothermia, which can significantly increase both morbidity and mortality.
